review_title: A formerly good company going through some very bad times
pros: When I joined Credit Suisse in 2008, it stood out from the other institutions I had worked for in having many highly qualified yet collegial employees. Often, in financial institutions, you either get  one or the either.  It had the entrepreneurial aspects of an American firm, with the work environment quality that you get in an European institution. It was a pleasant and enjoyable place to work, one in which me and my team worked hard for because we were valued, and felt proud to work for Credit Suisse.
cons: Unfortunately, Credit Suisse has two major problems at present (it has others, but let's focus on the most important things). First, it is undergoing a costly and difficult major restructuring, and second it is not making any money.  These two issues are not unrelated, but in the current situation amplify off each other.  As a result, there have been at least 8 (yes, eight) sequential rounds of redundancies in London the last few years, more to come.  All the good of the past (people, culture, management) have been lost, with only third tier management and a demoralised employee base remaining.  Revenue and compensation like-for-like are bottom quartile when compared with other "peer" top-10 investment banks.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros:

The timetable to reaching a reasonable work/life balance as a Director or MD is so long if you start as an analyst that most just get deterred to doing something else.

pros:

cons:
I attended a workshop that outlined the promotion process. While I was not employed long enough to pursue promotion (2-3 yrs), the process seemed oddly subjective. From what I understood, unless one has the support of their direct line manager, they can never be promoted. Titles are also important within this culture and will dictate how much income one can earn and how swiftly they can grow within the organization. Even if experience meets requirements for a role, employees cannot skip title levels. job_title: Senior Operations Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: CS is a large international financial services company . It provides great opportunity for internal mobility to various locations around the world. An employee has the chance to be exposed to a wide variety of financial products. The company has excellent benefits, and as an organization headquartered in Switzerland, the firm takes an open minded approach to the way in which it treats its employees. Diverse company with a lot of good people.
cons: Investment banks typically require long hours. While the neighborhhod bank up the street is open from 9-5, employees at investment banks average at least 10 or more hours per day. Although the company tries to support "work life balance", the industry demands a high level of dedication. Front office jobs (sales, trading, research) are most highly sought after  (and most lucrative) and will require one to locate to a major financial center and have strong academic/ professional qualifications.  Whether you are in the front office or a support role, you had better be able to handle stress.

review_title: Credit Suisse is not what it used to be
pros: There is a gym on premise that offers memberships and massages at discounted rates.... That is about the only thing I still value at this place.
cons: I have been an employee for 6 years and over the past 2 years this place has really gone downhill.  The mood is depressing, people are fired/rifed every week or leaving on their own due to the uncertainty. The salary's are below market and the bonuses have all but disappeared.  They even cut our benefits last year because they claim we were over market in this area.  Furthermore, it is very difficult to get a promotion.  The process is not transparent and takes at least two years.  However, the problem is that your manager or organization most likely will not last long enough to complete the process.  My past two managers, both of whom have left the firm, have advised that in order to obtain a promotion it's best to change firms.

review_title: Okay place for average people, the best can do better elsewhere
pros: The company is truly multi-national. You will have opportunities to collaborate across time zones and cultures. The company culture permits you (if the circumstances allow) to relocate to one of the offices around the world.
cons: It's a corporate mammoth, so your individual qualities don't matter as much as they would at a smaller company. No matter how bright or motivated you may be, there are narrow limits on your pay grade and career path, depending on where you stand in the organization. You may find yourself among obviously much less capable or driven people than you, and the difference may not be obvious to the management or HR. Salaries are at the industry average, but competent and motivated people have better options elsewhere, where they can actually make a difference. Stability and job security used to be a selling point, but that is clearly gone with the recession.

pros:
Working for a global bank right after graduating college is a great resume boost.  There is potential to move positions within the company through the internal mobility program.  Although benefits were cut starting year 2015 they provide decent subsidized health care, dental, and vision.  There are also tiny savings on things like car insurance and verizon phone service.
Decent Benefits
cons:
Limited advancement out of an entry level role.  once you join as a ENO product controller there is a minimum of 3-4 years before even being considered for AVP.  From there an additiopnal 4 years or so is needed to try for VP.  The pay is pretty low considering the long hours you will put in.  

Overtime is Half time i.e $10-$13 per hour depending on your salary

job_title: Assistant Vice President  in New York, NY
pros: Compensation and benefits are good.  A very good company to work for when it comes to diversity.  The majority of the time the work is challenging but can become repetitive at times.  Even though most managers are good at listening to problems and solutions most of the time it takes a long time to get many things resolved.  Too much middle management and not enough decision making.  That would also be a downside too.
cons: People are very rude, feedback is very limited even from your own manager. The promotion process should be a lot more fair.  There is no reason why some people are promoted over others except if you are well liked or like to kiss butt.  Unfortunately when you do ask questions to your manager you usually get a blank look and no true answer to why you might not be promoted.  Yearly reviews are usually very poor feedback from the manager level too.

review_title: Credit Suisse had some amazing people but was less than perfect organizationally.
job_title: Institutional Derivative Sales in New York, NY
pros: The people.  Really talented and entrepreneurial.  It is one of the premier banks in the world and therefore you had access to an incredible network of people and product.
cons: The firm culture comes a clear second to the allegiance to your desk.  And that means that it is political and that you have to watch your back and that you have to discount the guys at the top who like the idea of a warm culture but don't have the mechanisms or people in place to create that.  However, Brady Dougan, himself, is an amazing guy and have only the best to say about him.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Good investments in Technology and online training content.
Good cafeteria in NY location. But very expensive. U get no subsidies of any kind. 

Cannot think of anything else.
cons:
Bad place to grow your career. Bad or poor hiring practices and rampant politics and nepotism have led to a toxic culture where hard work is overlooked and bad managers who should have been fired for flouting corporate rules thrive! 
They have good policies and practices on the books but somewhere along the way they have lost it. 
HR who is supposed to be the last line of safety against harassment and abuse are toothless tigers. 
I would recommend anyone joining this firm to use it as a starting point for a short stint and Look for better opportunities elsewhere. 
They have been singularly focused on cutting costs and have totally forgotten about the adage - what U pay is what u get!

pros:
- Only major bank not to blow up in this current recession
- Strong risk management, strong brand, smart people, great resources
- Lots of opportunities to make a solid career mark, if you get in front of the right people, and in the right group
cons:
- Despite being in a strong market position, hiring approach is anemic (it's like going through the Olympics to get an interview, internal or external)
- Due to the above, these days, most people are working to the bone; high levels of stress and burnout despite having "all the opportunity" in the world right now
- Networking is key to career advancement; if you can't do it, don't expect to go very far

review_title: Decent but not the best company for apprenticeships
pros:
+ Constant support from the HR team whenever needed
+ High salary for an apprentice when compared to other companies
+ You can join multiple teams throughout the apprenticeship 
+ Apprentices have the same benefits as normal workers
cons:
- Supervisors as well as HR team members hardly care about the hours you work each day/week/month

- As an apprentice you are never fully involved in the business operations of the team you are in because the supervisors are very picky when it comes to giving you access rights 

- If you have bad luck, your team colleagues are often very busy with their own tasks and therefore have no time to teach you something new

- Long travel times

- A job for after the apprenticeship is not guaranteed

job_title: Summer Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Credit Suisse has a great name and reputation. Working in IB can gain you a lot down the road whether its B - school, with CS or another firm.  Salary and benefits for full time are awesome and the opportunities for summer analysts to network is great.  You have planned events, multiple mentors and a chance to attend speaker series that are very interesting from those in different parts of the business.
cons:
the opposite from a so called meritocracy.  you have a regimented schedule of promotion and only a small % will get promoted at a different rate

Also all the common downsides of banking, i.e. no social life and set hours.  plan on being in a lot on the weekends and late nights(do get free dinner and cab home though)

also hard to get in from what i hear from a non-target school. girlfriend of mine had to walk through fire to get the job coming out of non-core.

pros:
Short commute, around half an hour. Cafe at work has very friendly staff.
Pays a reasonable salary. Office is reasonably uiet but that is because they got rid of so many people.
Comedy value, listening to management chatting at the coffee area isvlaugh out loud funny. Buzz words and platitudes abound. Favourite topic? Avoiding blame for anything which went wrong.
cons:
Everybody is afraid of losing their jobs. Whole of IT to be outsourced to poorly qualified people in India.
Zero prospects. A good kick up the backside to find a new job.
Company statements are pure fabrication. Management resemble rabbits caught in car headlamps.
The chief of our department has one mission, send it to India.

review_title: Not ideal for IT/CS professionals who are looking for career and growth.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Used to have a good benefits but things are going south very fast as company cut the 401k matching contributions by half recently and also saw similar cuts on various perks including travel, .

If you are in NYC working for a trader and provided he tops up your IT bonus every year, then things are better for you.
cons:
No long term career growth prospects for IT professionals esp. if you are not working in NYC.

No work life balance

Management has no regard or value for good technical IT engineers and therefore if you are relying on your technical skills for growth/promotion in this firm then you are heading for a big disappointment. There is no clear growth path for technology skilled employees.

Management rarely appreciates individual contribution. In my 10 years of career I hardly had 1 lunch outing with team where I did not pay for my meals.

Too many managers and too less contributors.

review_title: Long hours and not a lot of interaction
pros:
The pay isn't bad straight out of college, good benefits, 401k.

People are nice there, although there's not much talk in my department

Cafeteria food isn't bad
cons:
Hours are long and relentless

anti social environment

Stressful work environment.  Solving breaks is not easy, Hard to learn when your supervisor is having trouble solving some of the problems

Training isn't great due to the fact that they expect you to know their office jargon and all these acronyms even if you're new to the banking industry.  Too much info to learn in so little time.

review_title: Not the sexiest job, but a good job for sure
job_title: Banking Operation Specialist in Raleigh, NC
pros:
- Decent benefits
- young workplace environment (mostly everyone I work with in their mid-20's) which is less intimidating for a recent college grad like myself. From what I can tell, your enjoyment of your job at CS completely depends on the team you are assigned to. My team is very sociable and always talking, making work much more bearable. I see other teams in the office that don't seem to talk... ever. I don't imagine I could work on a team like that for very long.
- learning opportunities
cons:
-inconsistent hours. you never know when you're going to end up working until 7 and/or later.
-some weekend work
-Some managers (not all) seem like they don't want to be bothered by the "analysts" and their problems

review_title: Great for doing 9-5 job but nothing more
pros: Possibility to Work @ home. Workload was ok (not too many overtime) workload. Employee get special rates for mortages. Good childcare service. Good team spirit among colleagues (in IT), although company didn't do much for it.
cons:
Its a Bank, not an IT company (surprise, surprise!), although 40% of employees are in IT, it is pretty poor from an IT professional point of view. Working conditions (workstation, software, hardware, environment) are pretty poor and feels like being from from last century. The decision making processes is poor, too many stakeholderse involved, slow on simple decisions, incapable of making good decisions on complex matters. Incapable of running even smaller mid-sized projects. Software engineering process is overengineered and inefficient.
Profit sharing only for top-managment, when times are harder, the bonus payments are cut on the lower levels. When cutting down jobs, they do not really care about the employees (part-time working mothers, young family fathers have to go first).

review_title: Formerly great place going through many changes and challenges
pros:
Good junior talent pipeline
401K plan
Work life balance
cons: Mid level IT management have been there for too long. They have no vision or only talk big ideas, promote check the box exercises, over promise, don't spend enough time building career paths for others, have no power, show no accountability and move around into newer roles every few years making big bucks. They do not make any attempt to ensure fair compensation throughout the organization and are focused on cost cutting and creating new process that increases bureaucracy, lowers morale and ensures systems remain out dated. The good talent is walking out of the door and is being replaced by mediocre people.

job_title: Technical Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Awesome people, great work-life balance, great culture, strong investment in diversity, great opportunities to explore mobility to other roles internally
Started my career here out of college and have grown so much professionally as well as met a ton of incredible people!
cons:
The analyst program lumps all Technology new college hires together for the same salary, which means that it may be more or less competitive to other offers depending on what you majored in in college.
General sense that technology/back office is a 'lesser' role than front office/finance positions in the eyes of the firm as a whole. 
Lack of an Associate title in Technology means that new college hires have to wait 4+ years for a formal promotion, which gives a sense of a lack of upward mobility and stagnation and can be off-putting.

review_title: Extremely disappointing and full of deception.
pros:
Looks respectable on your CV
Company on the whole is reliable and has weathered various financial problems.
Good opportunities IF you are lucky enough to be selected for them (slim minority)
cons: Depending on which office you are in, dictates what services are available to you in terms of 'enticements' such as fitness centres, cafeterias with a half decent offer of food, somewhere to relax in free time, the age and state of the furniture and interior design.  ...or entire lack there of in every sense.   Apparently (and I do believe this) there are great colleagues and work mates in may of the sectors.  Hopefully you have more luck than I have had. Don't be lured in by the false job descriptions and sugar coating/over-exaggerating of real (limited) possibilties that you have once stuck inside the set frame work that you have signed up for.

review_title: Cost cutting driven culture in IT
pros: Credit Suisse provides above average user systems and infrastructure (like offices, the newest 27" monitors, nice environment in Zurich), above average social benefits and salary
cons: During the last few years the whole culture is driven by cost cutting and cust saving, and if you think about that the whole IT is directly attached to the CFO, you know that quick wins and TCO is higher stated as visions and long term investments.

pros: Credit Suisse is a good company to work with, with good support around internal mobility and flexible work hours  although long hours. Also offers work from home flexibility. If you are lucky, you may get to work on good technologies with free hand to suggest open source ones. Unnecessary processes won't come in between to stop your proposal like many other places.
cons: Absence of strong HR & policies and many things are left with managers to decide that brings huge subjectivity. If you are true believer of work and want your work to speak, this could be a wrong place to work as everything is decided by your manager including your salary - that's so bad - think what if you are not in the good books of your manager.

pros: Good hours for an IB, flexible work arrangement available, somewhat more relaxed than other IB environments, friendly work environment, good office location
cons:
All about deployment and cost cutting, not had an increase in comp for years, claims they value human capital but can't see that in action, as far as middle/back office is concerned, they are all about deploying as much as possible to India and Poland. Staff in those regions have much more career opportunities and increases in comp than NY or London based staff. Low morale, static management, outdated IT systems makes the work more difficult than it needs to be.

They let talented people leave, and are replaced by incompetent middle management. Also they try to push "grow your own" and "internal mobility" when in fact senior mgmt positions are often recruited from rival firms.

pros: Decent work/life balance on our team; bright junior bankers; ability to work with seasoned bankers on other teams and gain insight into their own experiences
cons: Our small team was headed by someone petty, reactionary, and protective of the team bully (despite complaints from three separate individuals about their actions). Short of going straight to Jim Amine, there was no other mechanism to prevent consistent caustic interactions that were rubber stamped by our boss. COO provided little meaningful support and became a secondary mouthpiece for the group head. Unfortunately, despite being a consistently high performer in my reviews and after years of dedication, I left because the culture on the team became so unbearably toxic and mimicked trashy behavior that I haven't seen since middle school.

pros:
Good work/life balance. Don't feel like I need to monitor my work email when I go home for the day. The firm respects people's personal time.

Strong focus on clients. They really do seem to have their clients' best interests at heart, unlike other banks I've worked at that are all about revenue.
cons:
They'll spend months and months to produce huge decks that state the obvious, but then rush execution and do it on the cheap.

The bank has issues but is on the brink of a turnaround.  The new CEO is held in high regard and has a history of moving quickly.  I'm optimistic for the future.

review_title: Average Investment Bank (just like the other 20 in midtown & on Wall Street)
pros:
- More relaxed culture compared to some U.S. banks (looking at you GS, MS, JPM, Citi, BAC)
- Fairly competitive pay vs. other investment banks
- Decent internal mobility, "grow your own" is strong at the bank
- Best Location of all the banks (next to Madison Sq Park vs. crammed up in airless & touristy midtown yikes!)
- Pays 0.5 overtime if you're summer analyst/associate doing banking
cons:
- Pretty average bank, not top of the line investment bank like Goldman/MS and doesn't always win biz b/c of its smaller balance sheet which doesn't allow it to compete with banking giants like JPM, Citi, BAC
- Certain groups (in banking for example) have horrible hours & horrible mgmt., BUT not any worse than other investment banks

pros:
-Education opportunities were generally quite good at CS, if you can convince management and you get lucky.
- Pay and benefits are okay, especially when compared outside the finance industry.
cons:
- salary raises are next to impossible without leaving and coming back
- promotions are equally difficult and are distributed like candy in every ther region but Switzerland
- only sycophants and narcissists are likely to get promoted
- performance review is catastrophic and has become a system for managing people out, resulting in burnouts and other psychological problems for target employees.
- benefits have been significantly stripped down over the last years and are quite poor now.
- CFO has been running the show for the last few years and the bean counters rule the roost.
- Change is not welcomed, yet it is inflicted on staff through incessant re-organizations
- Survival of the fittest is the modus operandi. Diversity, inclusion, fairness etc. are all paid lip-service to, but are rarely found. The internal propaganda machine is very powerful.

review_title: Great place for development and those who prefer performance evaluation over BS
pros: Lots of resources for education and development, more performance based advancement/slightly less political BS than other banking environments I've been apart of.  Great pay/benefits for performers. average to low for those who don't shine.  Slightly less of a men's club/back slappin environment which I found refreshing as far as younger employees reaching out to managment.  Work environment very research driven and prided on work.  Bottom line- if your in the business for the right reasons this is your home.  If your in it for the BS go to an ol' american bank where you wait your turn
cons: Very large company- no hand outs-have to seek out the right avenue/departments if you want to continue to climb in your interest area: kind of how life works though....

review_title: Low pay and peanuts for bonus in Credit Risk Management.
job_title: Credit Risk Analyst ENO in New York, NY
pros:
Strong internal mobility support, but they require that you stay in your current role for a year. I was outta there in 18 months so can't speak much.

Good gym - $40 bucks per month for analysts, more expensive the more senior you are.
cons:
Very very low pay. Came from front office into risk, two years experience when I joined, they paid $80k base (I started in November), no bonus come January, and the following January, $800 dollars (yeah you read that right, that's 1%) in base raise, and an $8k bonus. This was after strong performance exceeding expectations. I took advantage of the $10k per year tuition reimbursement (I was doing my Masters degree part-time), and management had the cheek to imply that the BONUS WAS LOW BECAUSE I ALREADY GOT a 10k reimbursement.

Bear in mind that the tuition reimbursements do NOT come from your team's budget. Could be a really bad boss. Stay away from risk management here.

Jumped ship 18 months later to a hedge fund, now 100k + 50k bonus. Good riddance Credit Suisse!

pros:
Competitive pay
Good and knowledgeable people
cons:
For people looking to get a challenging role, this is a wrong place to be.
Slow paced.
Too many processes levied
Bangalore has many vendors and you're forced to manage them
No free hand to design and implement
Never are the eggs kept in the same basket which cuts scope of work.
Office in Bangalore is inside TCS, so you won't feel as if you are working for a branded organization.
Feels too political sometimes as people are there in the organisation from a long time. Tough to get them to go your way.

review_title: Credit Suisse - good place to work for a couple years and then move on.
pros: Great pay package, great coworkers, great reputation in the industry, looks good on a resume.  Learned a lot from working there, good benefits and good tuition reimbursement offered.  Senior management competent.  I would say that ninety-five percent of the people that work there are very intelligent and highly educated.
cons: Difficult to be promoted within, if you do a good job they seem to want to keep you where you are instead of advancing you forward.  Makes no sense when they bring in someone from the outside when they should fill from within.  Also, they were hiring a bunch of idiots that drained the salary pool.  Although i've heard they let a lot of them go so it's probably better now.

review_title: Good place to learn about private banking but lacks a soul. Very male-dominated culture.
pros: Interesting international environment. Not terribly hierarchical at least mid-management downwards. Focused on processes but not obsessed with them. Good benefits for staff. Brady seems to be an okay CEO but his lieutenants left a lot to be desired.
cons: Quite politcal. Senior management does not walk the talk and seem to be focused only on their own advancement career-wise and financially. Big mindset gap between the American managers and Swiss managers. Cross-functional career opportunities rather limited.  Not focused on creating enough opportunities for women although they pay a lot of lip service to it. There is no woman in senior management with any real weight or real P&L responsibility.

review_title: Good to start your career not to make one.
pros: Nice atmosphere and pleasant people to work with. Good life balance/Charity/Events.
cons: You can feel that being based in Poland, people in NY and LDN don't really care about you and what you deliver. Ridiculous base salary (40-60% lower than local competitors) and even more ridiculous bonuses about 1/2 month salary not really based on performance. Incapacity of CS to keep good people (you see many of them leaving after less than 2 years).  Makes you feel like people who stays are the one that are not able to find something better elsewhere.

pros: Tier 1 bank. You work with a lot of smart people. If you are on the younger side, you will like the fast paced and intense work culture, opportunities to travel, live in or visit NYC etc.
cons: As with any organization, there are political tussles, but generally they treat people more or less fairly. Once in a while they seem to get hit with some fine or the other which penalizes everyone for the screw up of a few bad individuals. The bank cannot do anything about this, but the system should be geared to more going after the individuals that make mistakes personally rather than levying massive fines on the bank itself, as it is very unfair for all other employees putting in hard work.

pros:
It is truly an amazing bank to work for. The company culture Mr. Abbas has set within PC in Poland is topnotch. People are very friendly and willing to help, you always feel happy to go to work every day. There is no "cutthroat" environment. 

There is also an excellent work balance life, you will typically work 40 hours a week, and in some days you will have to stay extra, but then you can leave earlier. 

I truly love this bank and recommend it to anybody who is a hardworker and fun person.
cons: Downside is that it is quite difficult to understand what you are doing in the macro escale and many of the skills you learn are not really applicable to other jobs/projects. But I guess this is true for all corporation jobs.

pros:
Networking opportunities, although limited
Subsidized gym on-site, although shared with Barclays
Can't really think of any other pro, I don't believe there were any
cons: Waste of time. The project I was working on was a major waste of everybody's time, mainly because senior management wouldn't commit and lend a helping hand when diverging interests have arisen. Ultimately everybody would just pretend to be working, which is an even bigger waste of time...

review_title: Good for start, competitive salary but job is boring and small chance for development
pros:
- good salary,
- great people,
- benefits (cinema tickets or gym card, yearly bonus, language course),
- company's brand
cons:
- repetitive and boring tasks,
- limited access to tools (it's a swiss bank after all..), your productivity will drop significantly if your job depends on tools you will not be able to use but you are used to,
- no chance to develop (unless you want to become a "manager") and nobody to learn from,
- poor management on most of the levels (lack of charisma and true leadership, most promotions are based on seniority)
 - way too many managers (team leaders, sector heads, sub-sector heads, sub-sub-sector heads...you get the idea)

pros: Nice offices, nice people, free taxis home and £15 for dinner after a certain time, was really looked after and they were genuinely interested in me.
cons:
As with any investment bank - long hours, unnecessarily short deadlines for work that's subsequently reviewed several more times, unrealistic expectations, awful work-life balance.

Specifically to CS - your summer experience will very much depend on which team you're working for, and whether they're busy at that time. Some interns had very little to do, others stayed at the office into the early hours most days!

review_title: Preach something that is not done
pros: Opportunities to work in an international environment with various countries and large projects, a lot of skilled (technically speaking) professionals.
cons:
No management (only in theory, no one cares about your career, they exist only to make sure you arrive on time and to micromanage), no constructive feedback is given, people are not willing to help you learn so you can be up to speed and do your job, not many tasks for you to work in, you always have to be looking for work.
Older coworkers pick on you for ridiculous things like "why you don't come to the office at the same time I do?" (Even though you're not impacting anyone, and they have a policy of come to work whenever you want to).
Not many new projects you can take on after you joined you're stuck with what you got, they also want you to do tasks not related to your role.

review_title: Great experience, learned a great deal, great platform to leverage inside and outside of the firm.
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Competitive, fast paced, has great intellectual resources. I enjoyed coming into Credit Suisse during the growth years. Very fast paced and entrepreneurial, many development programs and access to some of the most talented people in the industry. Management is accessible and is actively participating in employees' development. Proper recognition procedures are in place.
cons: Despite claiming to be entrepreneurial, it has become too large for entrepreneurs to be able to enjoy working there. I fear for the company because the landscape is changing dramatically and I am not sure the firm is doing enough to stay ahead. Idea generation process is stifled by the regulatory regime where the management is afraid to do almost anything in fear of being in violation of some regulations.

review_title: Wage theft, retaliation, and worker misclassification thanks to Credit Suisse
job_title: Production Support Engineer in New York, NY
pros: I have a valid federal lawsuit filed in NYC against Credit Suisse & NTT Data, Inc. for misclassification as an independent contractor, failure to pay overtime, retaliation. I have numerous e-mails that I received from an attorney representing NTT Data, Inc. that confirm all of my allegations against Credit Suisse and NTT Data, Inc. Credit Suisse approved timesheets confirming I worked 50-hour workweeks on average in 2012 that I still haven't fully been paid for. It's quite possible that a thorough audit of Credit Suisse's labor practices may be conducted by one or more regulators. The U.S. Department of Labor issued updated guidance last week about what constitutes a joint-employer that strengthens my lawsuit. Losing to me in court may have additional consequences for Credit Suisse, such as whether shareholders keep or cease their investments in a company that is already a felon.
cons: In retrospect, I should have made a greater effort to identify additional people at Credit Suisse that were subject to similar labor practices to further strengthen my lawsuit.

pros: You get paid for the extremely laborious work that you do.
cons: Extreme politics, inner circles, director and VPs don't know what's happening in their shop. VPs don't know the business the are running, favouritism, shoot to kill attitude, spying scandals, policies are only on paper, high attrition, no backfills, major salary disparity between AVPs in the same function, my way or the highway attitudes of VPs and director who is also very disrespectful to juniors and a top hypocrite, this department (MyHR S&S) is not data driven therefore mid year and year end appraisals are a sham, totally haphazard way of running operations under the leadership of the new director who was hired from a startup, over commit and under deliver way of work, extremely unprofessional and non people friendly VP and Director layers including the lady on the VP platform role.

pros: It was rewarding. When I started with the firm, I was given the opportunity to build my own team, develop a reporting package used by sr management to monitor the group's risks and performance.  I was then challenged with enhancing the SOX documentation and testing, and then transitioning the work into the line.
cons: Given the recent downturn in the markets, along with senior management turnover, the environment has changed.  Employees are mandated to support why the firm needs them.  Management performs morning and evening rounds to see what time people come in and what they leave.  Employees are working longer hours.  Functions are being turned into production roles, with no opportunity for growth and expansion for those performing those functions.  Other functions are leaving NYC area entirely, which is contributing to the low morale.

pros: An inclusive and collegiate environment and a wonderfully diverse place to work. The people are great and the culture excellent. You should expect the hours to be a little longer in an organisation like CS, but sometimes you do what you have to do to get the job done.
cons: Banks and large organisations do not adapt or change quickly, Credit Suisse is no exception to this. You will need to plan, persuade and have patience if you wish to effect change here. That being said, CS is doing a pretty good job in the face of challenging global markets and tough regulatory conditions.

review_title: An emerging great place to be
pros:
Good salaries, mixed with a high performance and training requirement.
The leader in Zurich as an employer.
Senior management ensures company has the right sustainable strategy, and protects its high performers. A very dynamic and rewarding experience and company.
cons:
As part of the banking sector, all employees look at the salaries reported by the higher earners, employees always feel underpaid even when getting high salaries.
The work life balance can suffer and you are expected to work when needed or seen to be leaving the company in the lurch. Working hard and beyond the pale is recognised, but has to be played in a way that you do not become a doormat.

review_title: Started with high hopes - Faded with bad memories
job_title: IT Program Manager in New York, NY
pros: Easy to have internal transfers. Lots of training available - if you have time to take them its worth it.
cons:
Too much politics. Unfair treatment. 

If you are soft spoken and straight forward, this is not a place for you. Seen often times, managers with abusive manners get promoted. It all boils down to who you know. I have seen excellent talents leaving this place due to lack of recognition.

Promotions are very strange - Last year, Project Managers, who did terrible project mgmt , got promoted as Program Managers, managing Project Managers. 

Terrible work life balance - sometimes 80 hour weeks  - not worth it.

PS - AVOID Program Services in IT - worst management; rude behavior; offensive language.

review_title: Good workplace, culture and colleagues for techies (EQD / Risk dept)
job_title: Senior Software Developer in Hong Kong
pros:
* quite open and flexible culture to accept new and better technologies
* management is quite supportive to evolve / revamp legacy system with a modern architecture
* new systems / tools would be built on web tech and microservices instead of excel / macro like other banks do
* lots of passionate developers
* one of agile pioneer in the i-banking industry
* good tdd / bdd driven and pair programming culture
* deliberate recruitment process and hired a bunch of good dev so far
cons:
* It was flat and simple structure when I first joint in 2014 and it's more hierarchical now growing over times
* Infra team was quite weak, not responsive and not very helpful, a certain amount of infrastructure we need to build and drive it to happen by developers , e.g. domain alias, CI / CD pipeline
* too many red tapes

review_title: I completed this in a hurry so I could see the salary info, so take with a grain of salt.
pros: Exposure to very high level transactions, and direct access to the management teams of large cap companies. I don't know what other industry allows a person so young that kind of exposure.
cons: The time commitment. Like most investment banks, deal movement doesn't happen solely between the hours of 9am and 5pm. Conference calls can truly happen at any time, and action items for a junior person staffed on a deal can keep one working truly through a 24 hour time span. This has never happened to me personally, but I've been kept at the office until 3. So full disclosure there. However, after you get used to it, you really wonder what you did with your time if you're out of the office before 10pm.

review_title: Good culture in a difficult environment
pros: Senior management reasonable, trying to manage the business in a difficult environment where tough personnel decisions have to be taken on an almost daily basis. Management is generally visible and available for discussion. HR is trying hard to instill a culture of rewards that are of non-financial nature which is difficult to push through in a banking environment.
cons: Cost containment measures a major on-going focus, which can be dispiriting. Below-average comp. Regulation is a very heavy burden for investment banks, and CS is no exception. Over time, this has changed the type of person that works in an investment bank (not just at CS), such that the work environment is now less thrilling or intellectually satisfying.

pros: The promotional opportunities are endless. If your located in the major financial hubs the pay range is very competitive. If you enjoy exposure to various teams throughout the world the cross divisional collaboration opportunities are endless.
cons: I currently work for the COE center located in the Americas. The compensation is not on par with the market due to lack of competitors. Company is utilizing the market of recent college grads and locals intent to living in the Southeast. If you want a competitive salary you have to move to Charlotte. Promotions hinge on how much you impress your intermediate boss rather than how efficient and productive a worker you are.

job_title: Global Support Specialist (HelpDesk) in Morrisville, NC
pros: As a contractor, the hourly rate offered was decent.
cons:
While in training, the trainer stated that he was being asked to cram about 3-4 weeks of training into about a span of 5-6 days. He said he was not happy about having to do this, but his superiors wanted us up to speed and out on the phones as soon as possible.
We(those of us in training), did not feel that we were prepared to step out onto the call center floor and perform our job to the best of our abilities. If the training were more in depth, than maybe my experience would have been different at Credit Suisse. My overall rating, on a scale of 1-5, I would give my experience at Credit Suisse at a 2.5.

job_title: Operations Analyst in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros: Practically None. Unless you are homeless or starving and are desperate for a paycheck, please avoid this company. It offers nothing but grief.
cons: Management takes a very combative stance towards it employees. Managers often yell and snap at subordinates with no consequences as HR rubber stamps everything that they do. Further they are also able to pass the blame to their subordinates for anything that goes wrong and there is no opportunity for workers to refute their claims as HR just turns a blind eye. Also, no one really seems to know whats going on as there is a fair amount of turnover and restructuring and the information systems are a mess as management cuts corners with everything.

review_title: Great first job, learned a lot
pros: Good salary, benefits, offices all around the world (I worked in two). I was new to finance and learned a lot, initially through a graduate training course and then a mentor scheme and later from senior people on my desk.
cons: Being a huge company, there is a lot of internal regulations and procedures - even the simplest things seem to require hr and compliance to sign off. There's a lot of politics, so if networking and schmoozing isn't for you then this gets tedious. Little job security - Entire desks are regularly shut down with the associated redundancies and re-shuffling. Finally, work-life balance was very bad, big emphasis on measuring time at desk rather than real productivity or ideas.

review_title: Good place for building your resume but not your career
pros:
- Good benefits
- Flexibility to work from home when needed
- Internal mobility is encouraged
- Various opportunities to get involved in philanthropic, sports and social activities
cons:
- Promotion process is very opaque. There are no clear rules for what it takes to get promoted, and even when a manager nominates their employee for a promotion, the promotion request may get dropped for unknown reasons.
- Due to the somewhat high turnover rate managers come and go all the time, and often teams are left in a state of instability in between management and organizational changes. A lot of information and knowledge is also lost when people leave, which leads to more frustration.

pros:
CS has nicer than average people
The bank has a good skill pool in front office
cons:
CS has a culture of indecision and procrastination
It is managed by ageing management for the benefit of ageing management
Revenues keep falling, even on strong markets, as risk aversion stifles business
Also compliance is applied there with a view that if the regulator wants 100 CS wants 150, not only does this create costs, delays and paperwork but it is a significant handicap vs competitors who simply respect present laws and regulations instead of trying to go further than everyone else (which no one pays for)
London is a cash cow office, where compensation is held back to pay for the army of people who work less employed in Zurich
Finally CS is handicapped by FX and continuous fines paid for past misdeeds in private bank but whose burden is shouldered by present employees in other divisions  
Avoid CS in general, London in particular

review_title: Great learning opportunity, supportive senior management
pros:
You learn a lot here if you put in the effort. Great collegial atmosphere in NY office and senior management is very accessible if you prove your value.

Pay is good if you prove your worth and more than most peers. For last two years, I have had no reason to complain about bonus, it was taken care of.
cons:
Management takes time to evaluate you - so be prepared to shine for two-three years and then you get the recognition.

IT systems are really flaky and all IT spend seems adhoc. Would be great if there could be one uniform and over arching system to learn rather than a hodge podge of different systems with different UIs and data feeds.

Moving to onshore locations a little tricky and seems a matter of luck for some.

review_title: Could be a great employer - if all the available talents would be appreciated
pros: CS is an interesting place to work, offering good pay and some insights to the Financial Services Industry. there are interesting career development opportunities - in particular for graduates. There are big differences between various departments ...
cons: Compensation model is not very transparent, the (usual generous) year-end-gratification depends on the manager's goodwill; There is no obvious link to the annual performance review. In some areas, working extra long hours is the standard rather than the exception. There is too much inefficiency - and with that too much money wasted

pros:
Good work ethics.
Home drop facility.
Flexible work hours.
Less work pressure.
cons:
I joined this company fresh out of college and I regret my decision. If you are looking for a career in IT please think twice before joining.

Very poor middle management promises made by them are never fulfilled.

Very bad in terms of growth and pay hikes. 

The office politics impedes the growth. The pay hike reflects worst of IT industry.
The fines paid by bank due to frauds are reflected in IT employee's pay slip for next year.

The technological stack used here is decade older and there are very less new development opportunities. 

The company has literally nothing in terms of infrastructure, the offices are located at vendor location. The cafe is terrible. If you are happy with a desktop and ccd machine this is the place for you.

pros:
Chance to learn some new skills.
The pay was generally competitive.
Most developers very clever.
Probably good job for someone fresh from college, but not seasoned pros.
It wasn't the worst job that I ever had, but close.
cons:
Top heavy management. Too many bosses, not enough consensus.
Low life/work balance. Need to push back just to take lunch or time off.
Too much emphasis on process not enough on producing working system.
Parking a joke. Crowded, had to take shuttle from overflow lot most days.
Very crowded cubes. Everyone shares a cube with low walls with someone else. Can hear everything on floor. Very hard to concentrate on work. Layout is like a giant call center which isn't good for doing any kind of software work.

pros:
Good job security if you are working directly with the investment bank and not one of the ancillary units that are more susceptible to market fluctuations.

Good work-life balance for the most part in the back/middle office.

Good medical/dental benefits, decent 401(k)
cons:
Extremely bureaucratic and rigid promotional program does not instill confidence nor reward talented employees, which leads to high turnover.

Pay is subpar to peers and contributes to the high turnover to competing firms in other cities.

Possibly due to high turnover, those who are employed in non-revenue generating areas will remain employed unless there are firm-wide layoffs (read: those who should be fired rarely are)

review_title: Nice people but too bureaucratic environment that supports mediocracy
pros: I think people (co-workers) are probably one of the best reasons to work at Credit Suisse. People are friendly and willing to help others.
cons: Too much bureaucracy makes it an organization which favors mediocracy over meritocracy. My personal experience suggests that 'building a network' is more important in CS than delivering high quality results if you want to grow in the organization. Senior managment doesn't appear to have a long-term strategic view but is more busy with delivering short-term goals which keep the wall street analysts happy.

pros:
Depends what division you work in. If you work with financial products and the trading desk, it's a good ole boys club. If you support systems, it's much more inclusive.

The pay was excellent with great bonuses. I really liked how they conducted reviews and gave ample constructive feedback. They promoted a fantastic work life balance with different "fun" events to facilitate networking and relaxing during the long work day.
cons:
Incompetent managers. Seriously. I knew more than my direct supervisor and he would constently belittle me and keep me late to work on a project while he tried to figure out how to do the job.

The expectation that you stay late even if your work is done but your manager is still there.

review_title: Good work environment..but the bank is not doing well
job_title: IT Consultant in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
Good work life balance
They treat contractors well, just like full time employee. This is the best part.
Flexible working hours, but working from home is generally restricted. You need to provide a good reason to work from home.
No micromanagement, You are given enough freedom to take day to day decisions.
Great cafeteria !
cons:
Recent layoffs creating confusion
Plan to move some employees to NY office is not clearly communicated. This creates lot of uncertainty among the employees as they could not plan anything long term like buying property etc.
Management dont update employees about the new developments. They all sit in NY office and there is communication gap.
Each managers have their preferred employees in their group and you can survive only if you are in a group.
Benefits and bonus are not great .

pros: Decent pay, lots of products and analytical material, many good people, lots of untapped potential, work life balance is good
cons: When I started working there in 2013 I had the feeling as if the company just hit rock bottom and things are probably improving. After almost 4 years the situation is still the same. There are thousands of brilliant people working there but management has made it very clear that any kind of engagement is not welcome. So everyone is just sitting on their position, completely unempowered, waiting for the next organizational change to get them moved somewhere or fired. Clients are treated as a nuisance at best and as a  threat at worst.

review_title: Credit suisse - one of the last great investment banks
pros: Credit Suisse has a very relaxed environment compared to other bulge bracket firms.  We have been able to avoid huge losses even in a very tough market.  Although job losses have been experienced the number of total layoffs is much less than other large banks.  This is due to solid managment and senior leadership.  Great place to work with very intelligent people in both the back and front office.  Many members of managment are very understanding and approachable and take a common sense view of most issues, something that is lacking in today's business world.
cons: Somewhat of a beauracratic environment will dealing with certain groups.  Not always easy to understand your small space in such a large company.

review_title: Find a better place to work.
pros: If you get married, there is a 1 week vacation bonus.  Unfortuantly, you can only use this once, so people who get married and divorced over and over again will not benefit from this.  If you are thinking about getting hitched, Credit suisse is a great place to be.   There is nothing like a free week of vacation.  Guess it is probably bad if the best reason to be at a firm is a weeks vacation.
cons: It is a train wreck.  Nobody knows what direction the firm is heading.  Some very incompetent people controll way too much power.  Definatly a place to be causious about giving your resume.  I would much rather be at a better bank.

job_title: Assistant Vice President in Raleigh, NC
pros: My location offers great work/Life Balance. Benefits are good. Many forums to voice your opinion. Lots of opportunity to move to different departments and advance. They value stability in an industry where many peers are reckless which is seems to support job security.
cons: Constant financial scrutiny has made this industry (and company) much less financial rewarding. CS is fanatical about its view on control to the point of having more reviewers than actual doers.

review_title: Smart staff - but in need of training
pros: The chance to work with some of the brightest, most intelligent and often highly motivated people in almost any industry.  (I've worked in IT Consultancy, Mobile Telecoms, UK Public Sector, Insurance and Utilities).  These are the best and the brightest - although little or no sign of arrogance.  Just smart and well motivated.
cons: Education and training.  OK so we're on the steep downside of cost cutting, but I spend 40% of my time mentoring, educating and training less experienced staff, but find it an uphill struggle to get people on education and training courses.

pros:
Get salary without doing any work.

If you don't want to do any work, and want to be able to take breaks for tea, coffee, lunches as many times as possible, this firm is the best choice to join as TA.

A best way to ruin your career.
cons:
No relocation bonus was paid and had to take loan after college just to rent an apartment here.

(below) Average Salary.

No food. No gym. No fun, nothing at all.

Too much politics.

I regret my decision to join this bank. Work can be a lot more fun and contributing. Do not hire people if you have no work to give them. Many people seems like attending an 8 hour jail sentence just to get the salary.

review_title: Great place to start a career, learn a lot, and meet a great network of people
job_title: Sales Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Working with great, smart people that are driven to be the best in their field. The resources at your finger tips and the access you have to some of the best minds in the business is amazing. I find that people here take their job bust luckily most don't take themselves too seriously. The company treats you well. Training that new analysts and associates receive is the best on the Street.
cons: Stress and work/life balance. It goes to say that it is easy to get burned out in this industry if it's not your true passion. It's a very volatile industry right now so there is the very real danger of more future cutbacks which can be stressful.

review_title: stay/start if you have no other choice
pros: Decent reputation, relatively high job security (provided that you aren't a bigshot).  Benefits are good.
cons: For the IT back office area, lack of advancement opportunity, full of deadwood.  It is not uncommon to see people working for over 10 years with same (low level) title and very little pay raise.  However, if you move up and work in some less desirable areas, you better watch out as you will be the first to go when the axes come down.  The worst thing is, there are not that many desirable areas that you can go/choose.  Many people quickly got dragged into support roles and never make it back.

review_title: Defensive management, Survival game (NY investment banking review)
job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
- Healthcare and pension benefits are very good compared to what I've seen in other Wall Street company
- NY headquarters location, right by Madison square park
- Work/Life balance
cons:
- Management is poor, driven mainly by self-interest and minimum risk taking. A standard management practice is to follow what "Goldman is doing". The feeling is that the best managers left over time, leaving the bank with a layer of class B or even C executives. One of the consequences is the extreme lack of communication between managers and the associate/VPs, so if you are not joining as a manager you shouldn't expect a lot of involvement and learning from your superiors.
You're experience might vary, but I've heard the same refrein again and again from people in different NY groups.

job_title: Equity Research Analyst in London, England
pros: Considered a great school for research analyst and overall very decent research house overall. It's a bulge-bracket bank, which makes it a top choice for anyone starting his or her career in finance, brokerage, and investment banking.
cons: Very poor performance of the European group in general lead to zero bonuses in equity research in 2010-2015 for analysts and associates in general. So, there was no money to be made in the equity research roles. Therefore, the turnover is great, the atmosphere and environment are toxic. People are depressed and unhappy a lot of the time. As a result, politics is intense, too.

review_title: Many here are leaving or looking to
pros: Until recently it was a great place to work, good people, good culture
cons: Pay is ridiculously low and despite what they will tell you, not competitive, The New York office looks down on the Raleigh office, even here people are worried about losing their jobs, the place seems way off its former track. With the poor economic situation the bank is in the vultures are circling and management are infighting. Mood is not good and it is not fun any more.

review_title: Credit Suisse - if you have to be in financial services this is a good place to work
pros: I enjoyed working for the firm because of the people, clients and experience. It was a great learning experience from several perspectives. The company is a leader in wealth management and is growing its presence in the US. Training program is outstanding, as is the ability to develop new skills in different areas.
cons: You work long hours, compensation is highly variable based on market, deals can get from one team to another, and there is sometimes a lack of communication. Its also easy to get lost in the shuffle due to the sheer size of the company.

review_title: Better than where I was before this job.
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros:
I like the profit sharing, the immediate vesting of 401k matching and other benefits.  Really appreciate the onsite gym at a low price due to the AVP pricing.

Credit Suisse came out on top from the banking crisis.

Bottom line, I feel blessed to have a steady job.
cons: The hours are better than my last job, but that's not saying much at all.  It is still about who you know, not what you know.  My manager is in another country who has never even met me in person.  Wish there was better internal professional growth, as opposed to bouncing around between companies.

pros: Only a paycheck.  Nice cafeteria and the grounds are nice.
cons:
Bungling management and a cutthroat enviornment.  Lied to coming into the position and no training support for over 6 months and then only a minimum effort.  Mangement really not qualified and usually come from within the company with little or no experience in the role they are promoted to.  Worse still is they lie about their qualifications and insist they have experience when it is clear they have no clue.  I would not recommend anyone to invest their time working for Credit Suisse you will only be disappointed later on.  

Middle management promises to get involved to make things better but then drops the ball and ignores the problem.

review_title: Great people, Swiss mindset can slow progress down for upper management.
pros:
Intelligent, respective, very rarely run into jerks. 
Investment Banking environment is very creative and keeps you on your toes to do better for yourself and your team.  
People are hardworking and competitive, but not with each other as much as other companies. 
For a bank, the employees care about each other. Didn't screw each other as other banks have been rumored to do.
cons: As a swiss bank, it's over complicated and simple things become complex.  Tough to get things approved and move forward because everything has to be run by Zurich.  At times that is fine, but in a global role, I often felt my swiss counterparts weren't as sophisticated, but since the headquarters were in Switzerland we had to go by their rules.

pros:
Good lace to work if you want an easy job
Good increments. At east in double digits.
Awesome Internal Mobility(within India) opportunities
cons:
Too much of 'women empowerment' . Basically they treat women employees like the way our govt. treats reserved category i.e. they can continue to be 'daamad of company without doing any work.
Work is secondary. What is more important is your participation in other co-curricular activities. Many people are surviving(and doing really well) just because of this.
So if you are someone who wants to learn and work stay away as you will get disappointed.

review_title: smart, aggressive colleagues with all the support to excel personally
pros: great people in a very exciting industry.  great research as resource to add value to clients.  great structured products and product teach ins which keeps one abreast of the markets.  much time, energy and money to invest in its people via off sites, management seminars and for some select senior management candidates, career coaches.  a complete business model with priv banking, asset mgmt, investment banking
cons: no balance with personal life which is typical for this industry.  one must love one's job and not for the money else the 15 hour days are too long.  with much reward, there is much battle internally to gain the prize.  dont be shy.

job_title: Vice President in New York, NY
pros: Great company, great salaries.  I think their heart is in the right place on so many things.  And that senior management is making smart decisions and seeing ways to capitalize on recent market happenings for future success and growth.  I think the opportunities area actually limitless for those with a proactive nature and willingness to work hard.
cons: Need help with talent management.  There is no program for star performers.  Communication is constant, but seems scattershot.  There is no sense of cohesive identity which people chalk up to things being very very Swiss.

review_title: Nice time, but better leave before it is too late
pros:
Working in international project, rarely flexible of roles in projects. 
Able to meet a lot of different, interestint persons.
cons:
Line management rather poor. No relation between what you have reached in projects and bonus. 
Line management is able to show any carerr path.
Somethime chaotic projects when working with different locations, so local interests are then rather more important than overall interests.
If you are missed to negotiate to get a good contract at start time, then better leave because to be promoted in IT is rather difficult and of course to get a salary increase also....

review_title: Good but needs some work--Asset Management
job_title: Asset Management in New York, NY
pros:
Good training.
Friendly people.
Good work/life balance
Name recognition
Informal culture
Very good compensation.
Very international firm with a great diversity of people.
cons:
Gets political.
Shared services is very bureaucratic.
Upper management makes decisions erratically.
Exit opportunities ambiguous.
Zurich and New York sometimes have power struggles.
Cost controls need more work--too much costs are allocated to the businesses that they become unprofitable--streamline shared services and cut unnecessary costs, such as the large army of strategy advisers.

review_title: Used to be a great bank, but focus on offshoring is ruining the bank's culture.
job_title: Web Developer in New York, NY
pros: People are generally nice to work with.
cons: There is a recent and extreme focus on offshoring at the moment and for the foreseable future. Offshoring does not actually save money, only headcount. It's a shell game designed to play with the numbers and give middle and upper management their fat cat bonuses. What actually happens is that the contractors that are assigned to the job are not experienced or familiar with the project. Their turnover rate is high, their work pace is slow and they are mostly likey working on another firm's project while billing CS.

review_title: WAS a good firm to work for, but as of today, it is a very poor employer
pros: WAS a very good place, highly engaged workforce, work life balance was best in the industry, decent pay master. Please note that this is in the past. Today the place is in ruins, thanks to an executive who joined, messed up the entire thing and left. (applies to Pune only)
cons:
HR is simply a puppet in management's hands.
Your career and job is at the mercy of the management, and the management can be very very irrational.
People are not valued, they are simply a tool to advance management's agenda and vendetta. (applies to Pune only)

review_title: Amazing company to work with. Provides good work culture alongwith good salaey and other benefits
pros:
Good salary payout
Variable not included in your ctc. 
Every year bonus over and above ctc (depends upons dept.  Overall performance)
Flexi working hours
Good transport facility provided
cons:
Managers coming from service industry are spoiling the culture here.
Vendor employees do not take their job that seriously and this affects the tech teams and on payroll employees as well

review_title: Not a bad place to learn and grow.
job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Great place to launch career if straight out of college.  Definitely builds strong work ethics, and you do get rewarded for hard work and good performance.  The exit opportunities once you have completed the banking program are broad, and if you develop good relationships with your senior peers, they will definitely support your cause.
cons: Downsides are the bureaucratic nature of the company and the highly political nature of the work environment.  But those exist in any large corporation.  You just have to know how to play it to your advantage.  This again is not particular to the Company, but the work life balance is definitely not optimal.  You will work more than you have ever expected, and predictability of freedom is nonexistent.

pros: see the world under reasonable travel policies, work hard but generally get recognized when you are successful.  Efforts are not rewarded, only success - this is a good thing.  Performance is important in finance - otherwise, well, take a look around the world at what happens when you've got incompetent and/or dishonest people gaming the system.  Like any place, quality of the people vary, but the good ones are as good as anywhere else - find them and learn from them.
cons: Hours can be long, so go in with your eyes wide open.  First couple of years you'll need to prove yourself before getting interesting work - don't be disheartened - everyone goes through it.

review_title: Nice supportive place to work, but not always focussed on excellence
pros: As a bank, it is still functioning and profitable, if not very profitable. A good place to work, the firm tends to look after its own. Attention to internal mobility and training. In my experience people are allowed good flexibility in difficult times (eg stress, illness, family issues). A lot of the senior management have been with credit suisse for a long time, so there is stability.
cons: Of course there is a lot of cost cutting at the moment. This leads to insecurity, but also there are challenges due to reduced resources. There is a lot of ineffeciency in the bank, some from unproductive/obstructive employees, some from inadequate infrastructure. Generally there doesn't seem to be enough of a focus on high standards across the firm.

review_title: The Prime Services is a pretty horrible place to work. work life balance is horrible.
pros: I can't think of any. Initially I thought salary is a pro but other banks pay much more for similar profiles.
cons: They treat you like machines, give you work which is not very meaningful (Lots of number crunching and excel sheet process that you won't know what its for). In long run working here will not add much to your skillset unless you are working in a very key role which is rare. Most people end up leaving the firm in a 1 year. If you are lucky and stick around, they start giving you hints by the time you are in your third year, to look for another job, which makes sense, you are still doing the same work as a first year since your skill hasn't improved, and you are getting paid more.

review_title: Solid employer, honest pay for an honest day's work
job_title: Assistant Vice President in New York, NY
pros: CS doesn't have stumblebum managers like they have in Citigroup.  Also in my 4+ years at CS, I haven't yet been screwed by a dirt-rate bonus like GS gave me a few years ago.  CS's 401k benefits are also pretty sweet.   Other than that- the pay's fairly competitive- I have no complaints about it.
cons: It's extremely difficult to make VP in the IT track.  To become VP, you've to have to manage at least half a dozen people in your own team.  Meaning it's entirely too easy to work a decade in CS and still only have an AVP title.  What a morale drainer.

review_title: As my first job at a Large Cap Company, i´m learning a lot. But there aren´t much opportunities.
job_title: Analyst in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros: It´s a large cap company. It´s one of the most respected world wide banks. I´m having plenty of opportunities to learn a variety of topics.
cons: I can´t see much opportunities. At my unit (Brazil) there is a prejudice against graduated at other universities not the one they want, so even if you´re good they prefer call someone from other company (even with a higher salary).

pros: The benefits were good.   The time off was better than average.  There were no blackout periods for time off, which was nice.
cons: Pretty much everything else.   The work load was impossible.  They expect you to work all hours of the day/night.  I was asked to come in on Sunday nights to help with our Australian office (it's Monday to them).  It was very cutthroat.  People on your own team were willing to sabotage you to get themselves ahead.

review_title: Former Operations Analyst - Only Single 20 somethings with no life apply
pros: If your in your 20's, not married and fresh out of College with no real relationship or life, this is the perfect place for you to work. You get PLENTY of overtime.
cons: If your in your 20's, not married and fresh out of College with no real relationship or life, this is the perfect place for you to work. If you have ANY of the above, apply elsewhere. Not to mention, you don't get paid time and half, you just get half time for overtime.

review_title: New management has changed the culture of the firm for the worst....
pros: Good benefits and compensation for employees.

review_title: Solid Internship - risky if looking for FT offer
pros: Credit Suisse's Sales and Trading was a great learning experience, not only because of the exposure interns received by working at a world class bank, but also because of the structure of the program and the attitude of the firm. Like their competitors CS's S&T internship introduced interns to all the relevant concepts and practices necessary for a career in S&T. The week long training course offered at the beginning of the internship was very well done and though hurried was thorough. Interns were placed on a single desk to the duration of their internship giving them the opportunity to form strong relationships (if they chose to) as well as complete a single project. The single desk placement also allowed for a much deeper understanding of a specific role in the firm. Additionally Interns were required to attend morning research meetings and were required to attend weekly talks given by managers in other groups (commodities, IBD etc).
cons: The single desk placement was a double edged sword for many. While it provided a lot of benefits in giving interns a chance to get to know their managers and teammates, it also prevented them from seeing other groups which they may have interacted with better. Interns placed into Equities were easily able to sit with members of the Derivatives groups but this would be on their own time and generally they would not complete projects with that group. As each group had its own interns, asking for work in a team different from the one assigned to you could be seen as "poaching" opportunity from another intern. The scope of the projects was also varied and some interns felt they did not have a chance to show their potential. Projects ranged from fairly rigorous computer programming (for those qualified) to more mundane research papers/presentations. Interns with rigorous projects often felt they were unable to sit with other groups and experience more of the firm. Interns with very simple projects felt that they were not given a chance to show their value add. A final note about the group placement is that it radically impacted your chances of being brought on full time. This internship took place in the summer of 2008 in the Hong Kong office, and as a result hiring was down significantly. Those interns that were brought on full time were isolated into specific groups that had available head count. These groups were able to hire all or most of their interns while other groups were unable to hire any despite indicating that the intern had performed at an exceptional level and would have received employment in different economic circumstances.

review_title: Credit Suisse offers a great bulge bracket experience for junior bankers.
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in London, England
pros: Credit Suisse is a great bulge bracket bank with a good reputation on the street. The vast majority of senior bankers have access to leading companies and junior bankers get a chance to work on front page transactions. Coverage groups also execute a lot of their own deals, so analysts and associates get good experience.
cons: In an ultra-competitive industry the cream is at the top, so some times CS will struggle to win deals from Goldman and Morgan Stanley. Analysts are coddled there like nowhere else (from talking to colleagues at other banks) and so the job of an associate is a little tougher.

pros: The firm has a lot of momentum after the financial downturn, as several of its major compeitors (i.e. Lehman, Bear Stearns, Merrill Lynch) are no longer around.
cons: There is no life-work balance in investment banking. People will ALWAYS expect you to put your job ahead of your life. Vacation is generally something one has to "earn" and actively seek; otherwise, you'll spend all your time in the office.

review_title: It is not a bad place to work
pros:
Credit Suisise is located in centralized locations within the central business district
Fellow colleagues are mostly willing to share information.
cons: The management is not transparent in the future plans for some of the functions in Credit Suisse. Not all of the managers see the big picture and also inadequate emphasis on employee development and work life balance.. The management information system infrastructure is very fragmented and requires a lot of manual work to come out with the necessary management information required which saps away efficiency of staffs.

review_title: Great Starting Place, but little room for Advancement
pros: CS is one of the few investment banks in the Raleigh area. and pay is very competitive. CS offers many philanthropy opportunities and lots of professional development classes.
cons: Not many management opportunities in the Raleigh office. Most managers are brought down from NY office or hired externally giving little advancement opportunities for Raleigh employees in the RTP office. In order to move up you will need to wait a long time or move to another office.

pros: You'll find 90% of the people very friendly. Less stressful. Christmas party means everyone eats together and gifts are passed out via raffle. Often get to leave early before a holiday. Nutritionist comes on site for 1 on 1s and does classes. Cubes are nice and big. New office spaces being built all the time. Good health insurance for a reasonable price.…
cons: Departments are not treated equally. A lot of people smoke. Employee manual is confusing. Some people get away with stuff that others get nailed for. Exiting the driveway (going left) is VERY dangerous between 4:50 and 5:30pm. Office politics vary by department.

pros: Credit Suisse has wonderful businesses and great teams under the umbrella. Their client base values their opinion and support. You won't have a problem getting a meeting with potential clients coming from Credit Suisse, but you will struggle to deliver at times based on the pace at which the firm moves.
cons: CS can be fairly bureaucratic to navigate. There are a number of barriers to starting new businesses and executing on ideas. There's more organizational risk to doing things here than at other places.

pros: CS is a strong brand and a market leader in many areas over the years - although changes are afoot with the major restructuring and job losses happening in 2016 after the arrival of a new CEO.
cons: CS has rested on its laurels in some areas with many senior staff having been there for years and years and fairly reluctant to consider let alone embrace change - which is probably why there is such a restructuring occurring now with a new CEO who arrived from outside.

review_title: The promise does not live up to the expectation, even though it has some great people.
